Comments_List: Learned more than in the rest of my Yale career combined!
I learned a great deal about everything from survey design and implementation, large scale project logistics, all the details of the US resettlement program, and lots in between.

This was one of the best courses I've taken at Yale. Implementing an extensive multi-pronged IRB approved survey of a diverse and vulnerable population is the most valuable kind of research experience. I came into the course with a solid background on refugee issues, and this course taught me far more than I was already aware of when it comes to US resettlement. I think a year long version of the capstone could be a great asset to even more developed final projects to the benefit of both the students and the clients.
It should be a year long project. We were rushed, in over our heads, and were not able to produce something we were truly proud of. More time would be incredible.
In my opinion, the capstone  needs a mix of development and security people (we had all security), and I also think a prerequisite should be having all of the math global requirements done.
Absolutely, for its occasional flaws, the capstone program remains the highlight of the Global Affairs major for undergrads. Its the reason you should join Jackson in the first place as a sophomore.
